title: Display full grant metadata in web UI
description:
The web UI doesn't show all grant.yaml fields like requested_start_date, research_gov config, etc.

## Current state
- Only shows basic fields (name, foundation, deadline, amount)
- research_gov section with directorate, division, PI info not visible
- requested_start_date not displayed

## Desired state
- Show all metadata from grant.yaml in a collapsible 'Details' or 'Metadata' section
- Group by category: Basic Info, Research.gov Config, NSF Sections, etc.
- Make fields editable so changes sync back to local via pull

## Fields to add
- requested_start_date
- duration_years / duration_months
- directorate, division, program_announcement
- PI name/email
- organization UEI
- repo_url, solicitation_url

## Related
- Sync push now supports nsf_config JSONB column
- research_gov section added to grant.yaml schema

title: Chrome extension for Research.gov form auto-fill
description:
Create a Chrome extension that can read grant.yaml and auto-fill Research.gov forms.

## Features
- Parse grant.yaml from local filesystem or sync from grantkit.io
- Auto-fill Cover Sheet fields (directorate, division, PI info, dates, budget totals)
- Pre-populate text fields from responses/ markdown files
- Validate before submission matches local data

## Technical approach
- Chrome Extension with Manifest V3
- Content script for Research.gov domain
- Options page to connect to grantkit.io account or select local grant folder
- Could use Chrome's File System Access API for local files

## Why
- NSF has no submission API
- Manual copy-paste is error-prone
- Ensures submitted data matches git-tracked source of truth

title: Add grants directory configuration with first-run setup
description:
When running grantkit commands, prompt user to configure their grants directory if not set.

## Current problem
Grants end up in random places (e.g., inside the grantkit package repo itself).

## Proposed solution

### First-run experience
```
$ grantkit sync pull
Welcome to GrantKit! Where would you like to store your grants?

  [1] ~/grantkit-grants (recommended)
  [2] ~/grants
  [3] Custom path...

> 1

Created ~/grantkit-grants
Configuration saved to ~/.grantkit/config.yaml
```

### Config file (~/.grantkit/config.yaml)
```yaml
grants_dir: ~/grantkit-grants
# Future: default_foundation, templates_dir, etc.
```

### Behavior
- All grantkit commands use configured grants_dir
- `grantkit init <name>` creates new grant in grants_dir
- `grantkit list` shows grants in grants_dir
- Can override with `--grants-dir` flag or `GRANTKIT_GRANTS_DIR` env var

## Migration
- If running from a directory with grant.yaml, use that (backward compat)
- Offer to move existing grants to new location

title: Budget form UI matching NSF Research.gov interface
description:
Add a budget editor to grantkit.io that mirrors the NSF Research.gov budget form interface.

## Current state
- budget.yaml stores structured budget data
- budget_justification.md has narrative justification
- No visual budget editor in app

## Desired state
UI component that looks like the NSF budget form:
- Personnel Direct Costs table (Senior/Key, Other Personnel rows)
- Fringe Benefits row
- Additional Direct Costs sections (Equipment, Travel, Participant Support, Other)
- Indirect Costs section
- Year columns with per-year and total amounts
- Auto-calculation of totals

## Data flow
1. Read from budget.yaml
2. Display in NSF-style form
3. Edits update budget.yaml via sync
4. Can export numbers for copy/paste into Research.gov

## Why
- Reduces context switching between GrantKit and Research.gov
- Catches budget errors before submission
- Single source of truth in budget.yaml

## Reference
See Research.gov Budget (Prime Organization) form for exact layout

title: Go-to-Market Strategy
description:
Define launch strategy for GrantKit.

## Target Markets

### Primary: Individual Researchers & Small Orgs
- PIs at universities without enterprise systems (Cayuse, Kuali, InfoEd cost $$$)
- Nonprofits and think tanks (like PolicyEngine)
- Independent researchers, consultants
- Graduate students preparing first proposals

### Why not enterprise?
Universities already use established systems (700+ on Cayuse alone):
- Cayuse SP/Proposals
- Kuali Research  
- InfoEd Pre-Award
- Huron Research Suite

These handle S2S (system-to-system) submission to Grants.gov. GrantKit should **complement** not compete:
- Better writing/drafting experience
- Export to Grants.gov XML for upload to institutional systems
- Target orgs too small for enterprise licenses

## Launch Channels
- Twitter/X (research Twitter, #grantwriting)
- HackerNews (dev-focused open source angle)
- Reddit r/gradadmissions, r/AskAcademia
- PolicyEngine network (warm intros)
- NSF workshop circuits

## Content Marketing
- Blog: 'How to write an NSF CSSI proposal' (use our real submission)
- Tutorial: 'Git-based grant management'
- Comparison: 'GrantKit vs Cayuse vs manual process'

## Integration Strategy
- Grants.gov XML export enables institutional users
- Chrome extension for Research.gov as lightweight option
- API for programmatic access

title: Browser agent integration for automated NSF submission
description:
Integrate with browser automation agents (Playwright, Puppeteer, or AI browser agents) to programmatically submit to Research.gov.

## Options to explore
1. **Playwright/Puppeteer script** - Deterministic automation, needs maintenance when UI changes
2. **AI browser agent** (e.g., Claude Computer Use, Anthropic's tool use) - More resilient to UI changes
3. **Selenium Grid** - Enterprise option for institutions

## Features
- `grantkit submit --dry-run` - Preview what would be submitted
- `grantkit submit` - Actually submit via browser automation
- `grantkit export --format=grants-gov-xml` - Export to Grants.gov XML format as fallback

## Considerations
- Need to handle 2FA/authentication securely
- Should capture screenshots/logs of submission for audit trail
- Must validate all fields match before final submit

## Related
- Grants.gov XML schema could be intermediate format
- Chrome extension (beads-xxx) is lighter-weight alternative

title: Export to Grants.gov SF424 XML format
description:
Generate Grants.gov-compatible XML packages from grant.yaml and responses/ for programmatic submission.

## Why XML is better than browser automation
- **Official submission path** - Grants.gov XML is a supported, documented format
- **System-to-system (S2S)** - Many institutions have S2S submission systems (Cayuse, Kuali, InfoEd)
- **No UI scraping** - Won't break when Research.gov redesigns
- **Audit trail** - XML package is the actual submission artifact

## Market context
Universities use enterprise systems (Cayuse 700+ institutions, Kuali, InfoEd) that accept S2S XML.
GrantKit targets individuals/small orgs without these systems, but XML export could enable integration.

## Technical details
- SF424 Research & Related form family
- XML schemas available at grants.gov/forms/sf-424-family.html
- NSF-specific guidance in NSF Grants.gov Application Guide (NSF 24-006)

## Implementation
1. `grantkit export --format=grants-gov` - Generate XML package
2. Map grant.yaml fields to SF424 schema
3. Embed PDF attachments (project description, budget justification, etc.)
4. Validate against XSD schemas before export

## Workflow
1. Write proposal in GrantKit (markdown + YAML)
2. Export to Grants.gov XML package
3. Upload package to Grants.gov OR use institution's S2S system
4. Package flows to Research.gov for NSF processing

## Resources
- https://www.grants.gov/forms/sf-424-family.html
- https://nsf-gov-resources.nsf.gov/pubs/policydocs/grantsgovguide0524.pdf
- https://www.nsf.gov/funding/submitting-proposal
